column1: 1#F-2018-006#Food-borne viruses#Food-borne infections caused by various viruses are a burden to the national economy and public health. In surveys of experts in the field of risk assessment (Delphi methodology)
column2: food-associated viruses were assigned to the ten most important microbiological hazards by Rowe und Bolger (2016). The focus of virus-associated outbreaks has so far been on noroviruses (NV) and hepatitis A. In recent years
column3: the importance of diseases with hepatitis E (HEV) has also increased
column4: as a result of which Switzerland subsequently launched a reporting obligation for HEV diseases. Globally
column5: NV is the most common cause of gastrointestinal diseases. Most outbreaks are due to contaminated leafy vegetables
column6: fresh fruit and shellfish. Due to global trade
column7: viruses from endemic areas are also expected to spread. Recent example: HAV outbreak in the EU associated with products from Morocco. The detection of viruses in food is a challenge because the isolation of viruses from complex food matrices is complex
column8: the viruses are heterogeneously distributed and sometimes occur in minute quantities. By means of thermal treatment
column10: HAV and HEV can be efficiently inactivated
column11: even in complex foods such as shellfish. It is more problematic with fresh fruit
column13: where thermal treatment is not an option due to the product characteristics.#Transmission in most cases through faecally contaminated water and food or through poor hygiene from person to person; important measures: Training of personnel who come into contact with food (producer
column14: processor
column15: cook
column16: waiter) usually effective; sick personnel avoid food contact; thermal methods relatively efficient
column17: even with complex matrix.#True#23.09.2018 00:00:00#10.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 2#F-2018-007#Mycobacterium avium ssp. paratuberculosis (MAP)#Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP) is a slow-growing bacterium and is the causative agent of Johne's disease (paratuberculosis) in cattle and other ruminants. The relationship between MAP and Crohn's disease is often studied in the literature. This disease is a chronic inflammation of the intestine. Although the link between MAP and Crohn's disease is not clear
column2: it is recommended to minimise exposure to the bacteria. MAP can enter the environment through excreta from livestock
column4: where the bacteria can persist. For example
column5: MAP has been detected in water and soil from dairy producers
column6: making contamination of vegetables possible. MAP has also been detected in the meat of cattle infected with Johne's disease. Despite hygienic work during milking
column7: MAP can enter milk via udders
column8: as the bacteria can be on the surface as well as inside the udders. Studies have shown that MAP can survive standard pasteurisation processes in milk. For example
column9: MAP has been detected in commercially available pasteurised milk samples. Although many studies have not detected MAP in food
column10: more positive results are expected as detection methods become more sensitive.#Old
column11: controversial discussion that also led to discussions in Switzerland as early as 2007 (see Feller et al. 2007) At that time
column12: a connection could neither be proven nor negated. It still remains unclear whether and to what extent MAP are responsible for Crohn's disease. If MAP - due to new methods - are now increasingly detected in past or high-paste milk
column13: these questions arise. These questions arise again when MAP is increasingly detected in past or high-paste milk.#True#17.05.2018 00:00:00#09.09.2024 00:00:00#10#true#20#`--- Primary ---

3#F-2018-008#ß-N-methylamino-L-alanine (BMAA)#β-N-methylamino-L-alanine (BMAA) is a non-protreinogenic amino acid and is produced by various free-living or symbiotic cyanobacteria (blue-green algae). It can also be produced by eukaryotic phytoplankton such as Diatoma and dinoflagellates. BMAA is a neurotoxin and has been linked in the literature to neurodegenerative diseases such as ALS (amytrophic lateral sclerosis) and Alzheimer's disease
column2: but the connection is not yet clear. The neurotoxin is ingested through the consumption of contaminated water
column5: fish and algae-based food supplements. The greatest concentrations of BMAA are present during the bloom periods
column6: but accumulations can also occur in the tissues of seafood and fish
column7: which means that BMAA can be ingested throughout the year.#Relatively new topic
column8: only few research results; connection between BMAA and neurodegenerative diseases unclear; BMAA has been detected in ALS
column9: Parkinson's and Alzheimer's patients; bound BMAA neglected until now

column1: 4#F-2018-020#Anthraquinone in foods#The Research Institute of Organic Agriculture (FiBL) carried out an expert opinion on anthraquinone in food on behalf of bio Suisse. The study was published in February 2017. The reason for this was the finding that residues were detected in various organic and conventional products in recent years. Anthraquinone acts as a repellent against birds and was therefore previously used to dress seeds. It is therefore considered a pesticide. In the EU
column3: its use has been forbidden for several years now because of health concerns. An analysis by the BNN (Bundesverband Naturkost Naturwaren)
column6: of several thousand datasets showed that smoked products in particular have a significant increase in anthraquinone content and that there are no differences between organic and conventional products. The authors assume that drying or roasting processes promote the occurrence of anthraquinones. It is further assumed that drying and possibly smoking processes are the main contributors to anthraquinone residues. The EFSA concludes in its expert opinion on anthraquinone as an active substance in plant protection products that carcinogenic effects related to anthraquinone cannot be ruled out and that the risk potential in mammals cannot be explicitly determined. The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) classifies the substance as a possible carcinogen for humans ("Group 2B").#The origin of anthraquinones (AC) is unknown (only assumptions); carcinogenicity not yet confirmed but correlations exist; anthraquinone is ubiquitous in the environment and has also been detected in the air; study showed that AC decreases during tea production#True#17.05.2018 00:00:00#11.09.2024 00:00:00#10#true#20#`--- Primary ---

column5: including the food industry. Blockchain works with decentrally stored data blocks and are also referred to as "distributed ledger" technology
column6: i.e. decentralised ledger technology (DLT). Data records are verifiable and almost impossible to manipulate as a result of decentralised storage
column7: which is an advantage. Some companies have already started to use blockchain. For example
column11: and Tsinghua University founded a "Blockchain Food Safety Alliance" to improve the traceability and safety of food. Initial trials were undertaken by the FSA (UK). A test by Walmart showed that to trace mangoes took six days before using blockchain and 2.2 seconds when using blockchain. The Food and Agricultural Organisation (FAO) of the United Nations also recommends the use of blockchain technology as a vital e-agriculture infrastructure component for building innovative food systems

8#F-2018-024#Microplastics#Microplastics are ubiquitous in various bodies of water. It is estimated that 4.8-12.7 million tonnes of plastic entered the oceans in 2010. Plastic pollution is classified as an emerging risk and poses a global threat to marine ecosystems. Various studies (and subsequent media reports) report contamination of microplastics in table salt and drinking water. The amounts vary
column2: but there is agreement that microplastics are found in table salt in different countries. Inorganic and organic particles can adhere to microplastics
column3: which are then absorbed by the human body through consumption of contaminated salt. In addition
column4: various types of plastic contain plasticisers
column5: which can have a negative impact on health.#`Microplastics have been detected in various salts and waters (China
column8: Baltic Sea); highest concentrations tend to be found in sea salt
column9: but also in salt lakes or rock salt; it is assumed that microplastics can also be distributed via the air; impact of microplastics on the human organism has not yet been researched
column10: but it has been proven that microplastics can accumulate in the tissue of marine animals. A controversial topic
column11: with two sub-areas to be distinguished: a) added microplastics (particle size ≤ 5mm) in products such as cosmetics and b) contamination from the environment. In connection with microplastics
column12: not only the plastic per se is to be seen
column13: but also additives such as plasticisers as well as adsorbed organic compounds. Rubber tyres (abrasion) and clothing made of synthetic fibres (loss during washing) are also named as sources of microplastics. Microplastics are thus also an issue for foodstuffs other than those with a connection to the seas
column14: such as salt

column1: 9#F-2018-025#Organosilicone surfactants#Organosilicone surfactants (OSS) adjuvants are silicone-based copolymers with super –penetrating
column2: -spreading and –wetting properties to potentiate the active ingredient against plant and animal pests and diseases. Over 700’000 tons of OSS are produced globally per year out of over 4.5 million tons of total of organosilicon production making this class of formulants the most widely used amongst all high-production chemicals for pollution worldwide. The metabolism and fate of OSS are almost unstudied on published literature. Toxic effects from OSS are observed in honeybees. Several recently published peer-reviewed journals on this topic highlight the safety concerns of organosilicone surfactant on humans and animals.#Enhancers are classified as biologically inert and GRAS (generally recognised as safe)
column3: which is why they are not regulated; OSS have a negative impact on bees and other insects
column4: which is why the question of the impact on humans arises; it is possible that the toxicity and uptake of OSS is dependent on the degree of polymerisation (molecular weight) and structure; light molecules are particularly affected; The FSVO has carried out a preliminary study on co-formulants (which also include OSS). It did not include certain substances and exclude others
column5: but identified co-formulants which are applied in significant quantities and which could potentially lead to residues in/on food. For this purpose
column6: the composition and sales figures for 2015 of the plant protection products (PPPs) authorised in Switzerland were examined. In principle
column7: OSS could also be recorded in this way. The results show
column9: that OSS do not belong to the quantitatively significant and potentially residue-relevant co-formulants of PPPs.OSS can not only be added to a PPP as a co-formulant
column10: but they can also be marketed and used as separate products (wetting and adhesive agents). Wetting and adhesive agents are added separately to the spray mixture of PPP and water. Wetting agents and adhesives approved in Switzerland are published
column12: including some that contain polyethermodified trisiloxane (an OSS). Wetting and bonding agents were not considered in the preliminary study. Sales figures for wetting agents and adhesives are not available to the FSVO. Agroscope has made an estimate for OSS based on PPPs containing polyethermodified trisiloxane. This rough estimate shows that approximately 0.7 tonnes per year of polyethermodified trisiloxane are applied via PPPs.Plant protection products (PPPs) consist of one or more active substances and several co-formulants. However
column13: only the food residues of the active substances and their metabolites are regulated. Co-formulants of PPPs are not assessed in a standard way. The Action Plan for Risk Reduction and Sustainable Use of PPPs therefore identifies a corresponding need for research.#True#19.12.2018 00:00:00#07.02.2023 00:00:00#10#true#20#`--- Primary ---

11#F-2018-027#Vibrio spp. in seafood#V. vulnificus and V. parahaemolyticus are marine bacterial microorganisms that can occur in seawater
column2: especially at warmer temperatures. They are the main cause of bacterial diseases caused by seafood. These pathogens are regularly detected in the USA and Asia. In Europe
column3: the pathogen is hardly ever found. There are fears that these pathogens will become increasingly important as the oceans warm up. The severity of the diseases caused by V. vulnificus can be described as very severe. According to literature
column4: the lethality rate is over 50% after infection. This makes it one of the most serious pathogens in terms of lethality in the area of food-borne diseases. The FDA regulation expresses this with a zero tolerance. In the EU and Switzerland
column5: there is no regulation of this pathogen. In addition
column6: various publications report the multiple development of antibiotic resistance in these pathogens
column7: caused by the use of antibiotics in aquacultures. Environmental and patient isolates show similar resistance profiles. These included resistance to ampicillin

12#F-2018-028#Azole resistance in Aspergillus spp.#Infections with Aspergillus spp. show a high morbidity and mortality rate in risk groups. Over 30 different species are responsible for this
column2: but the species Aspergillus fumigatus (A. fumigatus) is the most common. Azoles
column4: are used to prevent or treat Aspergillus spp. infections in humans and plants. Resistance of Aspergillus usually results from long-term treatments with triazoles. However
column5: A. fumigatus has been isolated from patients who have never been treated with such drugs. It is therefore suspected that resistant strains spread in the environment. These strains may have acquired their resistance through the use of triazole-based fungicides. Azole resistance is therefore described as an emerging problem. In Germany
column6: an increased number of aspergilloses have been observed in the last 5 years. In agriculture
column7: resistance to Aspergillus also seems to be increasing
column8: probably due to changes in cultivation techniques (minimum tillage) which may promote contamination and the growth of Aspergillus. Another risk is the emergence of cross-resistance. Studies have shown that resistant Aspergillus spp. are also resistant to medicinal azoles

column5: ST131 is the predominant E. coli lineage among extra-intestinal pathogenic E. coli (ExPEC) isolates worldwide. Retrospective studies have suggested that it may originally have risen to prominence as early as 2003. ST131 isolates are commonly reported to produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamases
column7: and almost all are resistant to fluoroquinolones. Moreover
column8: ST131 E. coli isolates are considered to be truly pathogenic
column9: due to the spectrum of infections they cause in both community and hospital settings
column10: and the large number of virulence-associated genes they contain. Previous investigations appeared to exonerate retail meat as a source of human exposure to ST131; recently in the United States
column11: a 1-year prospective study of E. coli from meat products and clinical cultures showed that E. coli ST131 strains are shared by both clinical samples from extra-intestinal human infections and meat samples from poultry.#In Switzerland
column12: studies have also been conducted; the presence of ST 131 was detected in vegetables and fish (Müller et al. 2016 ) and in surface waters (Zurfluh et al. 2013). column4: babies without hands or arms have been born for several years in three nearby heavily agricultural areas. The Agence de Sécurité Sanitaire (ANSES) has been commissioned to find the cause of this phenomenon by a committee of experts (comité d'experts scientifiques "CES"). Suspicion falls on pesticides or fertilisers as the reason for the malformations
column5: but CES speaks of no unusual accumulation of incidents: "Since no risk factors for ATMS ('agénésie transverse des membres supérieurs') have been identified and since these malformations are rare
column6: the expert commission (CES) does not yet recommend conducting a large-scale epidemiological investigation that would have to be observed for several decades. However
column7: CES believes that knowledge of the environmental causes of developmental anomalies is currently insufficient and recommends strengthening research capacity in this area." (ANSES
column8: 2019). Studies are complicated by the frequent lack of a reporting registry of birth deformities
column9: as well as the interaction of a wide variety of influences
column14: etc.
column15: that can lead to the development of a child with a developmental anomaly.#A report has been published by Santé Public France and Anses on the high incidence of hand malformations in babies in three regions of France. The causes could not be identified
column16: but some recommendations were made.It remains to be seen whether the malformations are indeed a statistical coincidence. Currently
column17: the classification system for medical diagnoses (ICD) uses a non-specific code for hand malformations. Thus
column18: the absence of a finger
column19: several fingers as well as an entire hand is coded under one digit. This means that the ICD is not suitable for recording and analysing hand malformations. For targeted research into the causes of congenital malformations
column20: there would need to be mandatory reporting nationwide and a central
column21: nationwide malformation register. In addition
column22: hand malformations would have to be coded according to the internationally recognised Oberg-Manske-Tonkin classification. Malformations at the age of one to two years would have to be diagnosed by an experienced hand surgeon and human geneticist

column9: and B. toyonensis species. B. cereus and B. thuringiensis genotypically hardly differ. Furthermore

column12: it is unclear to what extent B. thuringiensis could have an impact on food-associated intoxications. The greatest difference between the two species is limited to the presence or absence of plasmids. Plasmids often code exotoxins. The mechanisms of horizontal gene transfer would enable a plasmid exchange in the Bacillus cereus sensu lato group. Whether and how this happens has not been closely investigated yet. Thus
column13: whether B. thuringiensis can be detected in food samples has also not been investigated in greater detail. Recently
column14: certain strain of B. thuringiensis was described as being able to produce large amounts of sphingomyelinase; several other strains of B. thuringiensis demonstrated cytotoxicity in vero cell assays. Therefore

44#F-2019-064#Microbiological safety of whey powder#Whey powder is a by-product of the cheese production and is obtained from dried whey. It consists mainly of approx. 85% lactose and approx. 13% protein. In the past
column2: an increasing number of foods were withdrawn from the market because whey powder contaminated with Salmonella was processed in the products. 48#F-2019-078#Antimicrobial resistance in plant-based foods#Antibiotics are essential drugs. They are used to treat diseases caused by bacteria. However

column4: the Federal Council has adopted the comprehensive Strategy on Antibiotic Resistance (StAR)
column5: which is now being implemented in various fields. Antibiotic-resistant pathogens can also be found in foods. They can lead to increased resistance in humans. Resistance can be enhanced not only through animal products but also plant-based products. However
column6: we have far less information on plant-based products than on animal food products. Salads are popular foods in a balanced and healthy diet. They are often sold in a ready-tp-eat packging (plastic wrapping). It is known that such fresh products can be contaminated with hygiene-relevant germs. Different research groups have shown that these products contain germs that are resistant to antibiotics.#The Swiss Antibiotic Resistance Report 2018 does not contain any results on the significance of plant-based foods and antibiotic resistance. column7: various publications show that antibiotic resistance occurs in plant-based ready-to-eat foods. Genes conferring resistance to antimicrobial agents
column8: including resistance to drugs used to treat human and animal infections
column9: are found in bacteria isolated from foods of plant origin. Soil
column13: and fertilisers are common sources of contamination. column4: the most important source of human contamination is food. Indeed

column10: with a high prevalence in poultry. Milk and dairy products may also be affected. A. butzleri colonises diverse and numerous ecological niches

column17: pasteurised and UHT milk
column18: and in the production and storage of ricotta cheese and artisanal water buffalo mozzarella cheese. These findings have led to A. butzleri being considered one of the emerging pathogens in milk and dairy products/environments of the 21st century (Fusco et al.
column19: 2020). Some Arcobacter species can cause gastrointestinal diseases in humans and animals. These are usually associated with abdominal pain and nausea
column20: and watery diarrhoea but can also be asymptomatic. In general

column1: 83#F-2021-123#PFAS in food packaging#Per- and polyfluorinated alkyl substances (PFAS) are industrial chemicals that are used in numerous industrial processes and consumer products
column2: such as fire extinguishing materials. They are also popular in food packaging because the substances are water and fat repellent. However
column4: some of them have been shown to be liver-damaging
column5: toxic to reproduction and probably carcinogenic. PFAS are of particular concern because
column6: unlike other common contaminants that pass quickly through the human body
column7: they can linger for years and thus accumulate cumulatively. This property has given them the name "forever chemicals". PFASs can also enter the food chain through environmental pollution
column8: for example when plants are supplied with contaminated water or grown in contaminated soil
column9: such as near factories or places where products containing PFASs have been used for firefighting. From mid-2020
column10: Denmark will be the first country to ban the use of all PFASs in food packaging.#Research projects are currently being prepared at the Dutch RIVM that will deal with the use of perfluorinated and polyfluorinated alkyl compounds (PFAS). Specifically
column11: the aim is to develop proposals for restrictions on the use of PFASs. For the more than 4000 PFAS compounds
column12: a classification into "essential uses" and "non-essential uses" is to be made. (Source.BfR

column1: 85#F-2019-125#Nitrite in meat products#The World Cancer Research Fund (WCRF) 2007 stated that the consumption of processed meat may be linked to colorectal cancer. The cause is said to be nitrite curing salt
column2: which is added to many products to prevent the growth of food spoilage bacteria
column3: especially Clostridium botulinum. Several studies have investigated this hypothesis but have come to different conclusions. A connection between high nitrite intake from meat products and an increased cancer risk can neither be clearly proven nor disproven. Moreover
column4: it is not only the consumption of a food that plays a role in the development of the disease
column5: but the interaction between all lifestyle habits such as diet
column8: etc. Nitrite is not only absorbed through cured meat products
column9: but is also formed as a degradation product of nitrate-containing foods in the body. These are mainly plant foods
column10: as nitrite is an intermediate product in the supply of nitrogen to the plant. Examples of nitrate-containing foods are salads and vegetables such as rocket
column14: nitrate converted into nitrite can react with amines

86#F-2019-126#Mercury in permafrost#New studies reveal that permafrost is the largest natural source of mercury on Earth - with mercury levels twice as high as all other soils
column2: the ocean and the atmosphere combined. Climate warming threatens to melt this permafrost and gradually release mercury into the food chain. Mercury enters permafrost naturally
column3: as part of the global mercury cycle
column4: but also as a result of anthropogenic activities such as burning coal and petroleum. Once inorganic mercury is released
column5: it can be converted by microbes into methylmercury
column6: a potent neurotoxin. Eating fish from mercury-contaminated water therefore often leads to damage to the central nervous system and birth defects in humans. Released mercury can also enter the atmosphere and thus be distributed to other parts of the world
column7: where it usually settles in rivers

column1: Minamata Convention on mercury (2017) : The Minamata Convention draws attention to a global and ubiquitous metal that
column3: has broad uses in everyday objects and is released to the atmosphere
column4: soil and water from a variety of sources. Controlling the anthropogenic releases of mercury throughout its lifecycle has been a key factor in shaping the obligations under the Convention. Major highlights of the Minamata Convention include a ban on new mercury mines
column6: the phase-out and phase-down of mercury use in a number of products and processes
column7: control measures on emissions to air and on releases to land and water
column8: and the regulation of the informal sector of artisanal and small-scale gold mining. The Convention also addresses interim storage of mercury and its disposal once it becomes waste
column9: sites contaminated by mercury as well as health issues.

101#F-2021-147#Streptococcus agalactiae ST283 in fish#Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive bacterium that can cause various infectious diseases. Previously. the pathogen was mainly known to cause severe neonatal infections (e.g.
column3: but now S. agalactiae has also been linked to food
column4: specifically the consumption of raw fish. In 2015
column5: there was a large outbreak of severe invasive infections in Singapore
column7: which could be traced back to sequence type (ST)283 of S. agalactiae. Epidemiological investigations revealed that the consumption of raw freshwater fish (tilapia) was the trigger. Follow-up investigations used whole genome sequencing (WGS) to assess the prevalence of the bacterium more precisely. The result: S. agalactiae ST283 seems to have caused diseases in humans and farmed fish in Southeast Asia for decades. However
column8: much remains unclear. If ST283 is transmitted exclusively from fish to humans
column9: as was the case in the Singapore outbreak
column10: then cases of S. agalactiae sepsis in Thailand and Laos are predominantly a food-borne disease. However
column11: whether the transmission is from aquaculture to humans or vice versa
column12: and whether there is an as yet unidentified reservoir
column13: remains unknown. The germ could also be detected in tilapia from Brazil. Until now
column14: the serotypes ST260 and ST927 were known in Brazil
column15: but now ST283 also seems to be widespread. Based on import data of live tilapia from Singapore in 2014
column16: a study suspects that the genotype was introduced into the country by the imported fish.#Potential 'emerging issue'#True#12.05.2021 00:00:00#19.10.2024 00:00:00#10#true#20#`--- Primary ---

102#F-2021-148#Antibiotics to treat citrus greening disease#Citrus greening disease
column3: is a bacterial disease affecting citrus fruit and is spread through an invasive insect
column4: the Asian citrus psyllid (Diaphorina citri). Once a tree is infected
column5: there is no effective way of controlling or curing it. The disease poses no threat to humans or animals but can infest all types of citrus trees making it a serious threat to the global citrus fruit industry. Antibiotics are being used in some countries to handle the problem. In the USA
column6: there is a discussion about allowing farmers to use two antibiotics (streptomycin and oxytetracycline)  several times a year as a routine treatment. There is little scientific evidence on the long-term use of these drugs in crop environments. Further
column7: the use of antibiotics on a small-scale has previously shown to slow down the spread of the disease. This allows farmers to harvest a few more crops from infected trees
column9: the spread cannot be prevented. The potential use of antibiotics on a larger scale increases concerns about the developing resistance to antibiotics.##True#01.05.2021 00:00:00#06.08.2025 00:00:00#30#true#20#`--- Primary ---

108#F-2021-195#Residues of veterinary drugs in groundwater#Due to the intensification of food production in Europe
column2: veterinary medicines have become a critical component in animal husbandry. The administration of these products can potentially lead to their presence in environmental waters such as groundwater
column3: which is why they are now considered potential groundwater contaminants. In Ireland
column4: several residues of anthelmintic and anticoccidial veterinary drugs have been detected in groundwater. 22% of 106 sampling sites detected residues of anthelmintics in the range of 1-41 ng/L and anticoccidials in the range of 1-390 ng/L. Residues were higher near intensive farming sites. These veterinary drug compounds are associated with a range of acute as well as chronic side effects
column5: and their degradation products may have additional adverse effects.#The Federal Environment Agency (Germany) wrote a report on the topic in 2014 and came to the following conclusion: 'Overall and against the background of the worst-case approach

column2: the research group below performed RNA sequencing analysis with male mice that were fed isocaloric
column3: high-fat diets based on conventional soybean oil (high in linoleic acid
column5: a genetically modified low-LA soybean oil (plenish) and coconut oil (high in saturated fat
column6: without LA). Both soybean oil diets had similar but not identical effects on the hypothalamic transcriptome
column7: while the coconut oil diet had a negligible effect compared to a low-fat control diet. Dysregulated genes were associated with inflammation
column9: neurochemical and insulin signalling. Oxt was the only gene with metabolic
column11: and neurological relevance that was upregulated by both soybean oil diets compared to both control diets. Oxytocin immunoreactivity in the supraoptic and paraventricular nuclei of the hypothalamus was reduced
column12: while plasma oxytocin and hypothalamic Oxt were increased. These central and peripheral effects of the soybean oil diet correlated with glucose intolerance but not with body weight. In the coconut oil diet enriched with stigmasterol
column13: a phytosterol derived from soybean oil
column14: changes in hypothalamic Oxt and plasma oxytocin were not observed. The research team discovered about 100 other genes that are also affected by the soybean oil diet. They believe that this discovery could have implications not only for the energy metabolism
column15: but also for important brain functions and diseases such as autism and Parkinson's disease. However
column16: it has been indicated that there is no evidence that the oil causes these diseases. Furthermore
column17: the team noted that the findings only applied to soybean oil - not to other soy products or other vegetable oils.#One note about this study: the research team could not yet isolated which chemicals in the oil are responsible for the changes they found in the hypothalamus. Lawal et al. 2021 performed a phylogenomic analysis of 321 S. saprophyticus isolates collected from human UTIs worldwide from 1997-2017 and 232 isolates from human UTIs and the swine processing chain in a limited region from 2016-2017. They found epidemiological and genomic evidence that the meat production chain is a major source of S. saprophyticus causing human UTIs; the human microbiota is another possible origin. 129#F-2021-276#Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia albertii#Escherichia albertii was first described in 2003. This newly described enteropathogen and avian pathogen is often misidentified as E. coli (Ooka et al.
column2: 2012) or other members of the family Enterobacteriaceae due to its poorly defined biochemical properties and general lack of clarity. Furthermore
column3: E. albertii strongly resembles E. coli in its phenotypic characteristics. The presence of the major virulence factor intimin in E. albertii is well established
column4: while little is known about the presence of Shiga toxin (Stx) producing E. albertii (STEA). Stxs are the major virulence factors of Stx producing E. coli (STEC) in human infections. However
column7: often cause more critical symptoms in patients than STEC strains that do not produce intimin (Murakami et al.
column8: 2014). Several studies investigated the environmental prevalence
column10: genome and pathogenicity potential of STEA strains. STEA has been isolated from various animals
column13: but the natural reservoir of E. albertii is still unclear; this information would be important to determine transmission dynamics and prevent E. albertii infections. Given that patients in clinical outbreaks in Japan may be infected by water (spring and well water) or vegetables
column14: but not by meat
column15: the natural reservoir of STEA may not be large food animals (e.g. cattle and chickens
column16: the reservoirs for Shiga toxin producing E. coli and Campylobacter jejuni). Another possibility is wildlife
column17: which can contaminate water and vegetables in the area. In the 2020 study from Japan
column18: they detected STEA by PCR in 248 (57.7%) of 430 raccoons from Osaka
column20: and isolated 143 STEA strains from the 62 PCR-positive samples. In addition to Japan
column21: STEA has also been clinically isolated in other countries where raccoons live. Interactions between raccoons and other animals
column22: such as wild mice and wild boar
column23: may also be possible (Hinenoya et al. 2020).#E. albertii is known as an emerging zoonotic agent and has been isolated from various animals in Japan and the USA. It is likely that STEA is also present in EU member states and Switzerland
column24: but is misidentified as E. coli. To get a clear picture and take appropriate measures
column25: it would be good to know the exact STEA situation.The identification of the germ is not yet methodologically established
column26: which leads to misidentifications. New isolation methods are proposed (e.g. Hinenoya

column6: along with some other products such as palm kernel oil

column9: whether from natural sources or synthetic

column12: including a decrease in obesity due to their faster metabolism in the body [2]. There is also evidence to suggest some health risks
column13: such as the consumption of coconut oil leading to significantly higher LDL cholesterol levels compared to other oils [3] and the ability to induce insulin resistance [4]. In general
column14: however

column18: a substance developed about 40 years ago to inhibit beta-oxidation of fatty acids
column19: has massive side effects in patients
column20: but also show that ingestion of coconut oil or other MCFAs may contribute to chronic diarrhoea in patients with a mutation in DGAT1. The link between DGAT1 deficiency and chronic diarrhoea had already been shown in a previous study

column14: and the consequences for the natural
column15: social and built environment
column16: are known as the freshwater salinity syndrome (FSS). 'We used to think that the addition of salts was not a big problem
column17: ' says Kaushal
column18: a professor at UMD's Department of Geology and Earth System Science Interdisciplinary Center. 'We thought we'd sprinkle it on the roads in winter and it would wash away
column19: but we found that it stayed around and accumulated. Now we're looking at both the acute exposure risks and the long-term health

column21: and we're saying

134#F-2021-281#Pheophorbides and other hazards in algae products#Algae products with high levels of phophorbide (chlorophyll metabolite) have in the past (1970s) in Asia led to considerable health damage due to phototoxic effects in the consumers concerned. As a result
column2: official limits were set for certain product groups in parts of Asia
column3: but not so in the EU. It is therefore the responsibility of the food business operator to limit the content of pheophorbides in foods on the European market to a technologically unavoidable level in order to meet the requirements of European food law. The Japanese limit is 100 mg of pheophorbide present per 100 g
column4: or 160 mg of cumulative pheophorbide (i.e. the amount of pheophorbide present plus the amount formed by chlorophyllase activity within a three-hour incubation at 37°C) per 100 g. In Taiwan
column5: the limits only apply to dried seaweed with less than 7% residual moisture. They also do not apply to red and brown algae. According to the available literature
column6: the minimum amount of pheophorbide that is photosensitising is 25 mg/day. Other chemical hazards - associated with algae - concern in particular iodine
column9: as well as microbiological hazards (see further documentation). Recent studies also show that red algae can be used in animal feed to reduce methane emissions from cattle stomachs. Chemical hazards from algae could find their way into the food chain via feed.#Although no case reports of phototoxic effects following the consumption of algae products have been published recently

column7: cause infections outside the gastrointestinal tract. ExPEC include the following different pathotypes based on the host and site of infection; uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC)
column8: which are responsible for urinary tract infections (UTI); avian pathogenic E. coli (APEC) causing the most common disease
column9: colibacillosis in poultry; septicaemia-associated E. coli (SEPEC) and neonatal meningitis-causing E. coli (NMEC) responsible for septicaemia and neonatal meningitis
column10: respectively. ExPEC infections in humans are a significant cause of morbidity or mortality and are also mainly responsible for economic losses in poultry due to reduced production. Poultry could act as a source of extraintestinal infections such as urinary tract infections

column1: 140#F-2021-287#Human gut microbiome#The human gut microbiome is a diversified
column4: metabolically active and physiologically essential component of the human body. Scientific investigations have been conducted to explore detailed information on the establishment of the human gut microbiome
column7: factors influencing microbial community dynamics and the role of the gut microbiome in health and disease. Extensive research has suggested microbiome therapeutics as a futuristic medicine for various physiological and metabolic disorders. A comprehensive review of microbial colonisation
column10: commensal selection and immune survivability is still required to catalogue the essential genetic and physiological features for commensal engagement. The evolution of a structured human gut microbiome relies on microbial flexibility for genetic
column11: immunological and physiological adaptation in the human gut. The key features for commensalism could be used in the development of a tailored microbiome-based therapy to overcome various physiological and metabolic disorders.The influence of the gut microbiome on human health has come increasingly into focus in recent years. The microbiome in the gut has an important function in the metabolism of food components and chemicals and also serves as a barrier against harmful effects from the environment. The microbiome is a highly diverse community of microorganisms and includes bacteria
column14: and viruses. Ongoing studies show that microbiome structure and dynamics can have both a direct (e.g.
column15: direct metabolic conversion of chemicals) and indirect (e.g.
column16: regulation of gut barrier function) impact on human and animal health. The microbiome structure and dynamics are in turn influenced by external influences
column17: such as food or chemicals. There are now a number of studies showing an effect of additives such as artificial sweeteners or emulsifiers on the microbiome
column18: often resulting in impaired glucose metabolism or gut inflammation (Laudisi et al. 2019
column19: Roca-Saavedra et al. 2018). There is evidence from studies with mice that emulsifiers
column21: can disrupt gut homeostasis and lead to inflammation in the gut (Chassaing et al. 2015). Recent data also show that artificial sweeteners favour horizontal gene transfer in intestinal bacteria and thus promote the spread of antimicrobial resistance genes (Yu et al. 2021).##True#16.11.2021 00:00:00#03.12.2024 00:00:00#10#true#20#`--- Primary ---

143#F-2021-291#Circular economy#The Circular Economy (CE) is an approach that decouples economic activity from the consumption of finite resources
column3: opposes the linear economic model of 'take-produce-consume-waste' and replaces it with an economic model based on sharing
column7: refurbishing and recycling in an (almost) closed loop. Such a shift from a linear economy to a circular economy is expected to significantly support the achievement of the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)
column8: in particular SDG 12 (Responsible Consumption and Production). However
column9: the design and implementation of the circular economy requires careful consideration of the numerous trade-offs that may arise. This is a prerequisite for achieving SDG 3 (Good health and well-being).In the transition to a circular economy
column10: it will be crucial to identify potentially emerging risks to the environment and food and feed safety in a holistic and integrated manner in order to achieve an optimal balance between opportunities
column11: benefits and risks. It is important to ensure that food and feed safety and environmental health considerations are included at an early stage of research or policy initiatives related to recycling and the circular economy.#The efforts to move from a linear to a circular economy are part of the EU's European Green Deal. Linked to this are opportunities but also possible risks for food safety. These must be carefully examined and weighed up. See also ID 274 | "Upcycling" in the food industry#True#18.12.2021 00:00:00#18.12.2021 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

145#F-2021-293#Lactiplantibacillus plantarum - Plantacyclin B21AG#A traditional Vietnamese meat snack could be the key to developing a safe and natural food preservative that addresses the twin global problems of food waste and food-borne illness. The fermented pork snack
column3: is eaten raw but does not cause food poisoning if prepared properly. This is because Lactiplantibacillus plantarum B21
column4: which thrive in the fermented meat
column5: produce a special compound that destroys more dangerous bacteria.#Plantacyclin B21AG belongs to a group of compounds known as bacteriocins
column6: which are produced by bacteria to destroy rival strains of bacteria.Bacteriocins form holes in the membranes of the target bacteria. This causes the contents of the cell to leak out - effectively killing the bacteria. The problem is that most bacteriocins only work against one or two types of bacteria and they are not very stable under different environmental conditions. Only one nisin
column7: which came on the market in the 1960s
column8: is currently approved for use as a food preservative
column9: in a market estimated to be worth more than $513 million by 2020
column10: but this compound is temperature and pH sensitive

column1: 146#F-2021-294#Green Deal - emerging risks?#The Farm to Fork strategy is at the heart of the European Green Deal
column2: which aims to make food systems fair
column3: healthy and environmentally friendly. The Farm to Fork strategy aims to accelerate the transition to a sustainable food system. In doing so
column4: the Green Deal aims to:- have a neutral or positive environmental impact- contribute to mitigating climate change and adapting to its impacts- Reverse biodiversity loss- Ensure food security
column5: nutrition and public health and ensure that everyone has access to sufficient
column7: nutritious and sustainable food- Maintain food affordability while achieving more equitable economic returns
column8: - Promoting the competitiveness of the EU supply sector and encouraging fair trade.However
column9: this also entails proactively anticipating and addressing potential emerging risks to food/feed safety and the environment that may be associated with the transition to sustainable food systems. In particular
column10: this means assessing the food safety implications of the following practices:-Reducing the use of antimicrobials in livestock;-increasing the acceptance of healthy and sustainable diets;-Reducing food waste in the circular economy;-Reducing dependence on chemical pesticides and excessive fertilisation & increasing -organic farming.##True#21.06.2021 00:00:00#19.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

149#F-2021-297#ESKAPE pathogens transmission via food#ESKAPE is an acronym that encompasses the scientific names of six highly virulent and antibiotic-resistant bacterial pathogens
column6: Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Enterobacter spp. This group of Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria can evade or 'escape' common antibiotics due to their increasing multi-drug resistance (MDR). As a result
column7: they are the leading cause of life-threatening nosocomial or hospital-acquired infections in immunocompromised and critically ill patients worldwide
column8: who are most at risk. The food chain is one of the main drivers of MDR transmission
column9: as food is not sterile and can usually have microbiological contamination or become contaminated at certain stages of the food chain (i.e. cross-contamination
column11: the food chain can act as a driver for MDR spread
column12: enabling the survival or even multiplication of MDR pathogens. MDR transmission is not exclusive to foods of animal origin or fish; plant foods can also harbour MDR microorganisms
column13: as vegetables can be contaminated during primary production by water contaminated with faecal material from wastewater from surrounding farms. In general
column14: pathogens are not common in food and the main risk arises from the high prevalence of non-pathogenic microorganisms that can transfer AMR genes to other microbial species
column15: including foodborne pathogens. It is well documented that genes encoding resistance are transferable between different bacteria in farm animals and also from them to bacteria in food and humans by horizontal gene transfer (i.e. transformation
column16: conjugation and transduction).##True#19.09.2021 00:00:00#13.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 150#F-2022-298#Artificial sweeteners influence microbiome#New research shows that common artificial sweeteners can cause previously healthy gut bacteria to become sick and invade the gastrointestinal wall
column2: potentially leading to serious health problems. The study by Shil and Chichger (2021)
column3: published in the International Journal of Molecular Sciences
column4: is the first to show the pathogenic effects of some of the most commonly used artificial sweeteners
column7: on two types of gut bacteria
column8: E. coli (Escherichia coli) and E. faecalis (Enterococcus faecalis). Previous studies have shown that artificial sweeteners can change the number and type of bacteria in the gut
column10: led by scientists at Anglia Ruskin University (ARU)
column11: has shown that sweeteners can also make the bacteria pathogenic. It was found that these pathogenic bacteria can attach to
column14: the epithelial cells that line the gastrointestinal wall. It is known that bacteria such as E. faecalis that cross the intestinal wall can enter the bloodstream and accumulate in the lymph nodes
column15: liver
column16: and spleen
column17: causing a range of infections including septicaemia. In this new study
column18: it was found that at concentrations equivalent to two cans of diet soft drink
column19: all three artificial sweeteners significantly increased the adhesion of E. coli and E. faecalis to intestinal Caco-2 cells and differentially increased the formation of biofilms (Eurek Alert).The substance D-allulose belongs to the group of simple sugars (monosaccharides).The specific risk of favouring human pathogenic bacteria in the human body by food ingredients is to be considered as a possible "emerging risk". Aspartame
column21: has been repeatedly criticised for not being safe. This thesis has been taken up in various studies and examined by means of meta-analyses. The authors Millstone and Dawson conclude that it is premature to call aspartame 'safe' because the studies conducted by the EFSA to assess aspartame are flawed.Concerns are also raised concerning the sweetener D-allulose. The sweetness of D-allulose corresponds to about 70% of the sweeteness of household sugar (sucrose)
column22: but leads to a significantly lower calorie intake
column23: which is why the substance is advertised as a sugar substitute. The European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) has yet to issue an opinion on the safety of D-allulose as a novel food. The BfR (German Federal Institute for Risk Assessment) reported that the use of D-allulose as a food ingredient could selectively promote the growth of bacteria of the Klebsiella genus
column25: in the human body. From a risk assessment perspective
column26: the extent to which regular consumption of previously uncommon amounts of D-allulose as a novel food will undesirably influence the occurrence of Klebsiella spp. in the human gut microbiome remains to be scientifically determined.#The reason for the risk assessment of allulose was an increase in infections with the highly virulent germ Clostridium difficile in the U.S.
column28: was described in conjunction with the use of another low-calorie sugar as a food ingredient
column29: the disaccharide trehalose. This is no new criticism; what is new is that it focuses on the authorisation process per se.#True#25.05.2022 00:00:00#25.06.2023 00:00:00#40#true#20#`--- Primary ---

column5: the metabolic response of the participants' blood was measured after drinking potato
column6: rice and whey protein shakes. Appetite was also monitored over the following three hours to understand how these drinks may affect participants' hunger and food cravings.The researchers observed that vegan protein shakes resulted in a lower increase in blood insulin compared to whey
column7: while potato protein prevented any increase in insulin. This could explain the better blood sugar control after eating the plant protein and raises the question of whether vegan protein shakes are better for people who need to control their blood sugar levels

column1: 152#F-2021-300#Food waste: recycling leftovers#Various initiatives have been launched to reduce food waste. One of them is 'too good to go'. Too good to go
column3: is a movement against food waste and the app of the same name is the world's largest business-to-consumer marketplace for leftover food. In Switzerland
column4: more and more unsold food is sold this way. The idea of using technology to connect people in the fight against food waste was developed in Denmark in 2016 and quickly implemented across Europe. The Too Good To Go app connects people at the right time and place to reduce food waste. Currently
column5: 'to good to go' is active in 14 European countries
column6: and has also been present in Switzerland since summer 2018. The Too Good To Go app aims to create a win-win-win situation: Users receive food that has expired or is close to its expiry date at a reduced price. In addition
column7: there are campaigns that supplement the best-before date (BBD) with the phrase 'often good for longer'. Numerous manufacturers in Switzerland have already added this supplement to the best-before date on their products (Press room
column8: to good to go).Food waste is an economic problem
column9: but also a moral one. But what about food safety? In recent times
column10: food is being used beyond its expiry date
column11: but how safe is it? Since November 2019
column12: a retail chain in Switzerland has also been offering 'wonder bags' to counteract food waste. Bags filled with surplus products that can no longer be sold can be ordered and collected. The products cannot be selected by the buyer. (Source: LT Magazine
column14: 2019. 6.11.2019).#The approach of reducing food waste is to be welcomed. However
column15: there is a risk that products at the end of their shelf life could have increased germ counts
column16: which could lead to health problems for consumers if they are not consumed immediately or transported refrigerated. In addition to pre-packaged food
column17: leftover menus from kitchens are also offered. The customers do not necessarily know what they are buying
column18: as these are 'surprise boxes' with leftover food. This can be problematic for allergy sufferers. Inferior goods can also be sold fraudulently in this way. Efforts are being made along the food chain to reduce food waste. However
column19: such measures must not adversely affect food safety. Guidelines for the handling of food ?#True#04.07.2021 00:00:00#11.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 153#F-2021-301#Proteus mirabilis (MDR) on chicken meat#Proteus mirabilis is an opportunistic human pathogen. In this study
column2: a novel integrative and conjugative SXT/R391 element (ICE) named ICEPmiChnS012 was identified in multidrug-resistant P. mirabilis strain S012 isolated from a retail chicken in China. Whole genome sequencing revealed that ICEPmiChnS012 carried 22 resistance genes
column6: blaCTX-M-65 and blaHMS-1. ICEPmiChnS012 harboured 10 copies of IS26 and IS26-mediated genetic rearrangements caused variations in the HS4 region. According to the authors of the study ( Jieyuan Lu
column11: this study was the first time that an unusual gene cassette array dfrA1-ereA1-aadA2 was found in P. mirabilis. And this is the first report of the identification of aph3-VI and blaHMS-1 in the VRIII region in P. mirabilis. The conjugation experiments proved that ICEPmiChnS012 could be transferred to Escherichia coli EC600 by conjugation. These results showed that ICEPmiChnS012 was a specific ICE carrying the largest number of antimicrobial resistance genes in the family of SXT/R391 ICEs. This element could serve as an important vehicle for the spread of antibiotic resistance genes and should receive great attention.##True#05.07.2021 00:00:00#15.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 154#F-2021-302#Streptococcus suis - from pigs to humans#The Gram-positive bacterium Streptococcus suis is an emerging zoonotic agent that causes fatal infections such as septicaemia and meningitis in humans. In recent decades
column2: the number of reported human cases of S. suis infection has increased rapidly
column3: and three epidemics were recorded in China in 1998
column4: 2005 and most recently in 2016. The recent increase in the global spread of virulent S. suis suggests its adaptive evolution in humans. However
column5: this has remained largely elusive as no evidence of genetic adaptation to humans has been reported. The bacterium Streptococcus suis has long been known to cause swine disease. A genomic analysis has narrowed down where and when the deadly bacterium jumped from pigs to humans: in Europe in the 1960s or 1970s. To trace the evolution of S. suis
column7: 634 S. suis genomes collected over 36 years from pigs and humans in 14 countries. The genomes fell into three distinct groups
column8: one of which was found mainly in humans. This group included strains that caused severe diseases in zebrafish
column9: which the authors used as a model for human diseases. Some of these strains had been collected from pigs that showed no signs of disease
column10: suggesting that asymptomatic animals may have acted as vectors that transmitted the bacterium to humans. The researchers traced the origins of the human group to Europe during the 1960s and 1970s
column11: when the continent was exporting pigs worldwide.##True#10.07.2021 00:00:00#17.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 155#F-2021-304#Haff disease - caused by fish#Haff disease or black urine disease is caused by a toxin found in some fish. Symptoms include sudden extreme muscle stiffness
column6: loss of strength throughout the body and dark brown urine. They usually occur between two and 24 hours after eating fish or shellfish. The disease was first described in 1924 near Königsberg (now Kaliningrad
column8: in people staying in the northern part of the Vistula Lagoon. In the following fifteen years
column9: about 1000 cases were reported in humans
column12: and a connection with the consumption of fish (burbot
column13: eel and pike) was established (Wikipedia). Isolated cases still occur today. It is not known whether the odourless and tasteless toxin
column14: which cannot be destroyed by cooking
column15: is caused by improperly stored and packaged fish or by something the fish consumed.#In the United States
column16: a total of 29 cases of Haff disease were reported from 1984 to 2014. They were associated with carp
column17: buffalo fish
column18: lobster or Atlantic salmon. In recent years
column19: more cases have been reported from China.#True#16.08.2021 00:00:00#12.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 156#F-2021-305#Encephalitozoon cuniculi in foods (cheese)#Encephalitozoon cuniculi (formerly also called Nosema cuniculi) is a parasitic protozoan that lives obligately intracellularly in the kidney
column2: brain and other organs. It is classified as a microsporidian (Wikipedia). Experimentally produced cheese made from goat's milk enriched with Encephalitozoon cuniculi (E. cuniculi) or retail goat's cheese was fed to experimental mice susceptible to E. cuniculi infection in a study by Veckowà et al. 2021. The mice were killed during the suspected acute phase of infection and their tissue samples were subjected to molecular detection of specific E. cuniculi DNA. Specific E. cuniculi genotype II DNA was detected in the faeces and milk of three of the 99 goats kept on six farms in the Czech Republic. Under experimental conditions
column3: the spores of E. cuniculi genotype II remained viable in artificially enriched fresh cheese and were capable of causing infection in laboratory mice. DNA of E. cuniculi genotype I and II was detected in eight out of nine goat cheeses purchased from different producers/breeders in the Czech Republic
column4: and these cheeses were capable of causing infection in both immunodeficient and immunocompetent mice. The results of these experiments showed that spores of E. cuniculi genotype I and II can remain viable after cheese processing
column5: so that fresh and soft cheeses should be considered as a potential source of microsporidia.##True#10.08.2021 00:00:00#12.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 157#F-2021-306#Toxoplasma gondii in ostrich meat#Toxoplasmosis is a worldwide disease that affects humans and many animal species
column2: including birds. Antibodies against Toxoplasma gondii have been detected in ostriches from South and North America

(2021) was therefore to detect antibodies against T. gondii in farmed ostriches in the Czech Republic. Serum samples from 409 ostriches (Struthio camelus) collected from 9 farms were analysed by latex agglutination test. Antibodies against T. gondii were detected in 149 (36 %) animals. column6: indicate a risk of infection from ostrich meat to humans. Brain and heart tissues appear to be suitable samples for PCR detection of T. gondii DNA. Ostriches can presumably react as serological non-responders to T. gondii infection. column1: 158#F-2021-307#Borg - extrachromosomal elements#A team analysing mud samples in the Western US has found striking DNA structures that appear to detect and "assimilate" genes from microorganisms in their environment
column2: much like the fictional Borg from Star Trek
column3: who take over the knowledge and technology of other species. The extra-long strands of DNA
column4: which scientists have named in honour of the aliens
column5: join a diverse collection of genetic structures
column7: known as extrachromosomal elements (ECEs). Most microbes have one or two chromosomes that encode their primary genetic blueprint. But they can harbour many different ECEs and often share them among themselves. These carry non-essential but useful genes
column8: such as those for antibiotic resistance. Their enormous size
column10: 000 to about a million DNA base pairs
column11: distinguishes the Borg from many other ECEs. In fact
column12: Borg are so huge that they accounted for up to a third of the length of the main chromosome in their host microbes. In addition to their remarkable size
column13: Borg share several structural features: they are linear
column14: not circular like many ECEs; they have mirrored
column15: repetitive sequences at each end of the strand; and they have numerous other repetitive regions both within and between putative genes (Spektrum der Wissenschaft
column16: 2021). Do they also have a potential to cause disease or play a role in antibiotic resistance?#The significance of these extrachromosomal structures needs to be further investigated
column17: in particular whether they contain antibiotic resistance or other genetic elements that could influence the pathogenicity of an organism.#True#10.08.2022 00:00:00#31.08.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 159#F-2021-308#Colistin resistance - new transmissions#Colistin is a polypeptide antibiotic from the group of polymyxins. The antibiotic is mainly used in veterinary medicine and here predominantly for the treatment of intestinal diseases caused by bacteria
column2: but also for other infections.In November 2015
column3: a new mechanism was discovered by which bacteria can pass on the property of colistin resistance to other bacteria. This scientific finding has led to public debate about both
column4: the use of the antibiotic in livestock and the spread of resistance to colistin.Resistance to colistin has been described in animal isolates for several years. For a long time
column5: experts assumed that this was a non-transferable resistance that was firmly anchored in the chromosome of individual bacteria. The currently discussed colistin resistance
column7: is mediated by genes of a gene family that can be transferred from germ to germ by a mobile genetic element (plasmid). A plasmid is a ring-shaped DNA molecule on which genes for different properties can be located and which can be transferred relatively easily between different germs. The gene discovered in 2015 is called mcr-1 and was first described in China. Further investigations have shown that this gene can also be located on the chromosome. This means that it can then also be passed on to all bacterial offspring. Investigations following the discovery of mcr-1 have led
column8: also with the participation of the BfR
column9: to the description of further transmissible genes and their variants for colistin resistance in livestock (mcr-2 to mcr-10). The discovery of further genes of this type is to be expected still (BfR
column10: 2021).#Colistin resistance is also observed in salmonellae. Here
column11: it is of immediate relevance for consumer health protection due to the pathogenic properties of salmonellae for humans. Further information can be found in the scientific publication by Borowiak et al. (doi: 10.3389/fmicb.2020.00080). Resistance genes of this type have now also been detected in other bacteria (e.g.
column14: Acinetobacter spp.)

161#F-2021-310#Cocktail effects of agrochemicals#Cocktail effects and synergistic interactions of chemicals in mixtures are an area of great concern to both the public and regulators. The main issue is whether some chemicals can amplify the effects of other chemicals so that together they have a greater effect than predicted.Global concern about the widely documented decline of pollinators has led to the identification of anthropogenic stressors that individually adversely affect bee populations. Synergistic interactions between these stressors could significantly amplify their impact on the environment. To quantitatively assess the extent of this threat
column2: a meta-analysis of 356 interaction variables from 90 studies in which bees were exposed to combinations of agrochemicals
column3: nutritional stressors and/or parasites was conducted by Siviter et al. (2021). The authors found an overall synergistic effect between multiple stressors on bee mortality. A subgroup analysis of bee mortality found strong evidence of synergistic effects when bees were exposed to multiple agrochemicals at realistic levels
column4: but interactions were no greater than additive expectations when bees were exposed to parasites and/or nutritional stressors. All interactive effects on fitness
column6: parasite load and immune responses were either additive or antagonistic; therefore
column7: the potential mechanisms driving the observed synergistic interactions for bee mortality remain unclear. Environmental risk assessment systems that assume additive effects of agrochemical exposure risk may underestimate the interactive effects of anthropogenic stressors on bee mortality.#To what extent a synergistic occurrence of agrochemicals also influences human health
column8: remains an important question. As early as 2011
column9: three EU Scientific Committees (Scientific Committee on Health and Environmental Risks
column10: Scientific Committee on Emerging and Newly Identified Health Risks and Scientific Committee on Consumer Safety) expressed their views and formulated recommendations (SCHER
column13: Opinion on the Toxicity and Assessment of Chemical Mixtures
column14: 2012). A decision tree was proposed on how to assess such mixtures in terms of their risk. The findings of the Siviter working group are not exactly new
column15: but they can now be traced back to a large data base and confirm findings of earlier
column16: smaller studies. Active substances often occur simultaneously. Some combinations show synergistic combination effects that go far beyond what is predicted with current effect models. To date
column17: only the combined additive effects of similarly acting chemicals have been accurately assessed
column18: while the combined effects of dissimilar chemicals have in many cases been severely underestimated. Liess et al. (2020) have attempted to model these synergistic effects.#True#09.08.2021 00:00:00#31.08.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column2: transgenic expression of FTO in rice and potato led to an increase in yield and biomass of about 50 %. The study also shows that the presence of FTO stimulates root meristem cell proliferation and root bud formation and promotes photosynthetic efficiency and drought tolerance
column3: but has no effect on mature cell size
column6: plant height or ploidy. FTO mediates substantial m6A demethylation (about 7% demethylation in poly(A) RNA and about 35% decrease in m6A in non-ribosomal nuclear RNA) in plant RNA
column7: resulting in chromatin opening and transcriptional activation. Therefore
column8: modulating m6A methylation of plant RNA is a promising strategy to dramatically improve plant growth and crop yield.#Human genes
column9: which are incorporated into plants and lead to considerable improvements in crop yields

164#F-2021-315#Staphylococcal enterotoxins#Staphylococci (and their enterotoxins) are the leading cause of food-borne illness (CFTI) with a confirmed or suspected agent in France and are a major cause of food-borne illness worldwide. Staphylococcal CFTIs are due to the ingestion of heat-resistant staphylococcal enterotoxins (SE)
column2: preformed in food at the time of preparation. The vast majority of these CFTIs occur in restaurants
column3: school canteens or in the home. Staphylococci and ES are most often detected in food samples and more rarely in the vomit and stools of patients. Very often
column4: only ES are detected in contaminated food; the bacterial strains producing these toxins have been eliminated by the preparation conditions. It is therefore sometimes difficult to link ES to the producing strains. The detection of ES in food is therefore a crucial step in the surveillance of staphylococcal CAI.#ES are produced by toxigenic staphylococci as they grow. These toxins are formed in food contaminated with toxigenic staphylococci. Toxin production requires a bacterial concentration above 105 cells/g of food. ES are produced between 6.7°C and 45.5°C and are resistant to heat and digestive enzymes. They are destroyed by heating for at least 30 minutes at 100°C. Staphylococci
column6: are not resistant to heat treatments above 60°C applied for more than 60 minutes. S. aureus (or Staphylococcus aureus) is the most common species implicated in food-borne illness and the most pathogenic of the Staphylococcus genus. Other toxigenic species
column8: S. intermedius or S. argentus (recently identified as a new species disassociated from S. aureus)
column9: have been implicated in food-borne outbreaks
column10: but their presence in food remains poorly documented.#True#17.09.2021 00:00:00#07.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

173#F-2021-325#Sapovirus - zoonotic agent#Sapoviruses cause acute gastroenteritis in humans and animals. They belong to the genus Sapoviruses within the family Caliciviridae. They infect people of all ages
column2: both in sporadic cases and outbreaks. The clinical symptoms of sapovirus gastroenteritis are indistinguishable from those caused by noroviruses
column3: so laboratory diagnosis is essential to identify the causative agent. Sapovirus infections are a public health concern
column4: causing acute gastroenteritis in people of all ages worldwide in both outbreaks and sporadic cases. Outbreaks often occur in semi-enclosed environments. Outbreaks due to food-borne transmission of sapoviruses have also been reported. Sapoviruses are genetically and antigenically diverse. Currently
column5: reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) assays are widely used for the detection of sapoviruses from clinical samples because of their high sensitivity and broad reactivity and the lack of sensitive assays for antigen detection or cell culture systems for the detection of infectious viruses. Sapoviruses were first discovered in 1976 by electron microscopy in diarrhoeal samples from humans. To date
column6: sapoviruses have also been detected in various animals: pigs
column9: sea lions and bats (Oka et al. 2015). Sapovirus is thought to be spread from person to person
column10: through sewage infiltration into drinking water sources and via contaminated food. Among food-borne transmissions
column11: seafood is a recognised source of sapovirus infection.##True#10.11.2021 00:00:00#14.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

column1: 175#F-2021-328#Postbiotics#Postbiotics are functional bioactive compounds that are produced in a matrix during fermentation and can be used to promote health. column2: postbiotics can include many different components
column10: peptidoglycan-derived muropeptides and pili-type structures. Postbiotics is also a fairly new term in the field of 'biotics'. While there is a consensus for the definitions of pre- and probiotics
column11: one for postbiotics is still under discussion. A definition was formulated in 2021 by 'The International Scientific Association of Probiotics and Prebiotics (ISAPP)'. Postbiotics are defined as 'preparations of inanimate microorganisms and/or their constituents that confer a health benefit to the host'. Research to date suggests that postbiotics may have direct immunomodulatory and clinically relevant effects
column12: and there is evidence of the use of postbiotics in healthy people to improve general health and alleviate symptoms in a range of conditions such as colic in infants and atopic dermatitis in adults
column13: as well as in various causes of diarrhoea.#This is a new subject area

column2: the BfR issued a statement on vanadium. The background to this was the detection in mineral water or spring water
column3: where in some samples the levels of vanadium were above the de minimis threshold of 4 µg/L set by the "Länderarbeitsgemeinschaft Wasser". Maximum levels for drinking water
column4: mineral water or other foodstuffs do not exist. High levels in mussels and dark chocolate are known from the French Total Diet Study; the levels measured in cereal products and milk are lower. Cigarette smoke is also a source of exposure. For the assessment
column5: the problem arises that health-based guideline values of different magnitudes have been derived by various bodies on the basis of different studies and toxicological endpoints. The uncertainty in the health assessment of the occurrence of vanadium in food is correspondingly high. Only for vanadium pentoxide are there harmonised classifications for toxicological properties within the EU. On the basis of the available data
column6: the BfR concludes in its opinion in a weight-of-evidence assessment that vanadium compounds are to be regarded as genotoxic in vivo. The classifications of national and international bodies on carcinogenic properties only concern vanadium pentoxide or inorganic compounds after inhalation exposure. Oral studies on carcinogenesis are not known. Therefore
column7: it is unclear to what extent the data from studies with inhalation exposure to vanadium pentoxide are relevant for the oral intake of vanadium via food (including drinking water). No report is yet available on the ongoing National Toxicology Program (NTP) studies on genotoxicity. Furthermore
column8: a re-evaluation by the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has started in 2020. Also in 2020
column9: BfR has submitted a request to EFSA for health assessment in food and derivation of health-based guidance values. A timetable for EFSA's work on the topic is not yet available.#Oral studies on carcinogenesis are not known. Therefore

179#F-2022-335#Staphylococcus argenteus#`Staphylococcus argenteus has recently been proposed as a new species within the S. aureus complex (SAC). S. argenteus has been found in many countries and can pose a threat to human health. It is known to cause various diseases in humans such as skin and soft tissue infections
column2: sepsis and staphylococcal food poisoning. A study by Wakabayashi et al. (2022) investigated the prevalence of S. argenteus in retail fresh food and poultry slaughterhouses in Japan. Of 642 food samples examined
column3: S. argenteus was successfully isolated in 21 of 151 (13.9 %) chicken samples. No isolations were confirmed from pork
column5: fish or vegetable samples in retail markets.The findings of Wakabayashi et al. (2022) suggested that chicken meat was significantly contaminated with this bacterium and could be a source of human disease. The molecular epidemiological study by Wakabayashi et al. (2022) found that meat processing plants could be partly responsible for the spread of the bacterium from the environment to food and vice versa.Staphylococcus argenteus has been recently established as a novel species of the Staphylococcus aureus complex. It is known to cause various human diseases
column6: such as skin and soft-tissue infections
column9: although the source of infection has not been clearly described. In food poisoning cases
column10: the source of bacterial contamination in food is unknown.

column1: Staphylococcus argenteus was isolated from chicken meat and slaughterhouse samples.
Twenty-one isolates from chicken meat were classified into 14 genotypes.
WGS showed possible bacterial contamination of chicken meat in the slaughterhouse.
