column1: 180#F-2022-336#Nano coating of foods#There is currently a lot of investment in research to develop new types of food packaging and a trend towards sustainable and also edible forms of packaging. Edible packaging is usually made of sustainable
column2: biodegradable material. On the one hand
column3: this includes packaging such as yoghurt pots that can be eaten
column4: but also edible coatings that are placed around the food. In Switzerland
column5: edible coatings of fruits and some vegetables are permitted
column6: e.g. beeswax (E 901) as a coating for apples. Provided that the substances are approved as food additives for the respective food. What is new is that more and more packaging or coating agents are now being developed in nano form. Depending on the application
column9: nanoemulsions or even nanoencapsulations. A current example is the development of a nano-cellulose layer for fruits and vegetables
column10: which is made from pomace (pressed out fruit and vegetable peels). The project is a collaboration between Lidl and researchers at EMPA. The reason for using nano-forms is manifold. Nano-form coatings allow thin edible layers on the food (about 5nm thickness). Coatings based on nanotechnology usually also allow better regulation of moisture in the food and better gas exchange for longer shelf life. In addition
column11: nanocoatings can enable other functions such as the incorporation of so-called nanosensors in food
column12: which indicate the spoilage of food (so-called "smart packaging"). Various legal and health issues arise in the application. For example
column13: in the case of the cellulose developed by EMPA
column14: it is not clear whether the already approved coating agents (celluloses E 460-469) cover the newly developed cellulose or whether it would need a new approval. Secondly
column15: there are questions about the toxicity of the nanoparticles through the consumption of the edible layers
column16: which need to be carefully clarified before new nanoforms can be put on the market. A report by the RIVM in the Netherlands
column17: for example
column18: points out that specific risk assessments are needed for nanocellulose applications in the food sector
column19: and that these might even have to be considered as novel foods. Retailers and Empa (Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology) are researching protective cellulose coating for fruit and vegetable products. The innovative coating is made from so-called pomace (press residue) and in the future
column20: is to be used for retailers' products. The innovative project can reduce packaging and avoid food waste. No fresh vegetables are to be used for the novel protective coating
column21: only organic residues. At Empa's Cellulose & Wood Materials lab
column23: researchers developed a special protective cellulose layer that can be applied to fruit and vegetables within a year's time. The result: the coated fruits and vegetables stay significantly longer fresh. In tests
column25: the shelf life of bananas could be extended by more than a week.Other materials for alternative packaging and substitutes for plastics are being researched
column27: for example.#There is a clear trend towards more sustainable food packaging that is made from natural raw materials and does not generate waste. While the ecological and technological benefits of these new products are relatively clear
column28: the associated risks have not yet been sufficiently clarified and researched. The FSVO is confronted with both legal questions about the classification of these products and health questions about the nanoforms of these products.The project seems to be making great progess. The question about what effects such a coating will have on food safety remains unanswered. See also Post-harvest treatment
column29: ID 149.  Other developments include fibroin-based packaging in silk production: ApplPhysRev.#True#16.03.2022 00:00:00#09.09.2025 00:00:00#50#true#20#`--- Primary ---

The authors conclude that probiotics have been shown to be effective against various types of cancer
column4: but also that there is a need to evaluate the adverse effects of probiotics (gastrointestinal side effects
column8: abnormal stimulation of the immune system) (Sankarapandian et al.
column9: 2022). Cancer patients have compromised immunity due to primary disease
column11: and radiotherapy. The effects of probiotics in this population may differ from those in healthy individuals and raise several critical issues (Lu et al.
column12: 2021). A new publication states that Lactobacillus can alter the function of immune cells (macrophages) in the pancreatic tumour environment and stimulate cancer growth (Hezaveh et al.
column13: 2022). The mechanism involves the metabolisation of dietary tryptophan by bacteria in the gut
column14: which leads to an inactivation of immune cells involved in tumour control. This is not the only indication of potentially harmful effects of probiotic microorganisms
column15: even independently of the presence of cancer. Among others:

column1: 183#F-2022-339#Coxiella burnetii increase in animal population#Q fever is an acute disease caused by the bacterium Coxiella burnetii. The natural reservoir of the pathogen is cattle
column6: some wild animals and ticks. Infected animals often show no symptoms
column7: but excrete the pathogen mainly via birth products of farm animals (e.g. placenta)
column10: urine or milk. In the majority of cases
column11: infection in humans occurs through inhalation of dust containing the pathogen
column12: but also through direct contact with infected animals. People who are in close contact with animals (animal owners
column14: slaughterhouse employees
column15: etc.) are particularly affected. Depending on the wind conditions
column16: however
column17: people in the immediate vicinity of infected animals can also become infected. In about half of the people infected
column18: the infection causes no symptoms or only mild flu-like symptoms that disappear spontaneously. The other half experience sudden fever
column21: fatigue and headache
column22: which can be complicated by inflammation of the lungs
column24: heart muscle or brain. Q fever is usually treated with antibiotics to prevent the disease from becoming chronic. Besides sporadic cases
column25: outbreaks can also occur.There is a steady increase of reported cases in the animal population since 2014 in Switzerland; cattle: 2014: 54; 2021: 131; Goat: 2014:3; 2021: 19; sheep 1; 2021:10). In 2020
column26: a total of 51 human cases of Q fever were reported to the FOPH
column27: which corresponds to a reporting rate of 0.6 new cases per 100
column29: there were almost twice as many cases due to an outbreak
column30: with 101 cases. The outbreak was most likely linked to two infected goat herds in Ticino. There is no similalr increase in the human population as observed in the animal population.##True#31.03.2022 00:00:00#01.09.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`--- Primary ---

187#F-2022-343#Herbs and spices - fraudulent manipulations#Culinary herbs and spices are valued for flavouring food and could also provide other beneficial properties
column2: such as antioxidative and bacteriostatic effects as well as certain pharmacological activities. Their supply chain is complex
column4: and globalised. Europe is one of the world’s leading importing regions for herbs and spices
column6: mostly spices from East Asia. Most of the spices are produced in countries where certain post-harvest processes such as drying and cleaning may happen before being shipped to the importing country where they are further cleaned and sanitised before being packaged and distributed either to other food businesses or for retail consumption. At each stage
column7: fraudulent manipulations may happen and the more often the material is transferred from one operator to the next
column8: the fraud opportunity increases#The coordinated control plan is until now the largest investigation into the authenticity of culinary herbs and spices in terms of participating countries (21 EU Member States plus Norway and Switzerland) and samples analysed (1885). column2: also known as Pine Nut Syndrome (PNS)
column3: is an uncommon dysgeusia that generally begins 12–48 hours after consuming pine nuts. It is characterized by a bitter metallic taste
column4: usually amplified by the consumption of other foods
column5: which lasts 2–4 weeks. Recent findings have correlated this disorder with the consumption of nuts of the species Pinus armandii . Inedible types of pine nut may accidentally or fraudulently find their way onto the market and cause lingering taste disturbances. This phenomenon peaked in France in 2009
column6: with 700 cases reported to the network of poison control centres in August of that year alone. Although there have been far fewer cases in recent years – around ten annually – the problem has not gone away and a slight increase was observed in 2021. ANSES reiterates the recommendations regarding this type of poisoning: report any persistent bitterness after eating pine nuts and keep the packaging so that the product batch concerned can be withdrawn or recalled.Pine nuts are small oilseeds that are generally consumed as is
column7: or used to garnish a dish or a drink
column8: or in culinary preparations such as pesto. Despite health controls
column9: inedible (and therefore cheaper) varieties of pine nuts are offered for sale
column10: often mixed with edible pine nuts
column11: and can cause a particularly unpleasant taste disturbance called dysgeusia. This leaves a metallic and/or bitter taste in the mouth
column12: which is exacerbated by eating or drinking any kind of food or drink. Sensitivity varies according to the individual: after consuming the same product
column13: some will experience the adverse effect and others will not. An earlier retrospective study from March 2008 to January 2010 had counted more than 3000 symptomatic cases in France reported to the network of poison control centres after exposure to pine nuts. Most of these occurred in 2009 with a peak of around 700 cases in August 2009. This peak was due to the consumption of inedible pine nut species from China that had only recently arrived on the market.In Australia

column1: 201#F-2022-357#Bacillus cytotoxicus#Bacillus cytotoxicus is a member of the Bacillus cereus group. This group comprises closely related organisms of varying pathogenicity including the food-borne pathogen Bacillus cereus sensu stricto. Some members of the B. cereus group can cause two distinct forms of food-borne illness: Firstly
column2: the diarrheal syndrome that is linked to three enterotoxins - Hbl
column4: the emetic syndrome caused by cereulide toxin preformed in food. B. cytotoxicus was isolated for the first time in the context of a severe outbreak of diarrheal disease leading to fatalities and was described as a species in 2013. The organism harbors a specific variant of the gene encoding the enterotoxin cytotoxin K designated cytK-1. It has been reported that the cytotoxin K variant CytK-1 confers substantially higher toxicity than CytK-2. B. cytotoxicus is thermotolerant and might be missed using routine diagnostic screening for B. cereus group organisms at 30°C. Targeted screening at temperatures of at least 37°C has shown that dried food matrices containing potato starch very commonly harbor B. cytotoxicus.For instance
column5: a recent study found a prevalence of 95% in mashed potato powder sold at retail level in Switzerland. Recent reports from the UK suggest that B. cytotoxicus also occurs in association with insect-based foods
column6: which have recently gained popularity. In cytotoxicity assays
column7: the few B. cytotoxicus strains that have been characterized to date range from non-toxic to extremely toxic
column8: with toxicity surpassing the toxicity of a B. cereus outbreak strain (NVH 0075-95) used as a reference. Information on B. cytotoxicus is still limited and it is unclear if the organism’s capacity to germinate
column10: and exhibit cytotoxic effects in the intestine is comparable to that of B. cereus.B. cytotoxicus is a Gram-positive
column11: aerobic organism able to produce spores. The species description was based on five strains
column12: four of which were linked to foodborne disease (Guinebretière et al.
column13: 2013). B. cytotoxicus is thermotolerant and able to grow at temperatures of up to 53°C. Further characteristic features are the absence of starch hydrolysis and the dependency from tryptophan for growth. B. cytotoxicus also characteristically harbors the cytK-1 variant of the cytotoxin K gene.#`The B. cytotoxicus outbreak in a nursing home in France in 1998 had been caused by vegetable puree that exhibited 3.0 x10E5 CFU of B. cytotoxicus per gram food. A total of 44 cases were reported
column14: with six patients suffering from bloody diarrhea and with three fatalities due to necrotic enteritis
column15: making this outbreak the most severe B. cereus s.l. related outbreak in France (Cairo et al.

column1: 222#F-2023-005#Protein supplements : effects of a (too) high protein diet#"A high protein intake is great for losing weight
column2: but it's also great for athletes." With such and similar statements
column3: the importance of proteins in the diet is advertised. At the same time
column4: more and more "high protein" foods are available
column5: which - as the name suggests - have a higher protein content than their conventional counterparts. Proteins are essential for many functions in the body. But what are the consequences if the recommended daily intake is chronically exceeded? People who follow this "high protein" trend are particularly affected.A chronic excess of protein can have negative consequences in the long term. However
column6: these health risks are only discussed in the specialist literature; the general population is insufficiently informed about them. On the contrary
column7: protein-enriched products are now widely available in shops
column8: and big advertising campaigns by the industry promise health benefits thanks to these (expensive) trendy products. The lack of information about the possible negative effects of too much protein gives the false impression that the "healthy" amount of protein is unlimited
column9: in the sense of "if it doesn't help
column10: it doesn't hurt".Delimaris et al. (2013) conclude in their article that extra protein is not efficiently utilised by the body and can put a strain on the metabolism of bones
column11: kidneys and liver. According to the authors
column12: there is currently no reasonable scientific basis in the literature for recommending consumption above the RDA for healthy adults (= recommended daily allowance). Disorders of bone and calcium homeostasis
column14: increased risk of cancer
column15: disorders of liver function and accelerated progression of coronary heart disease are mentioned as health risks associated with long-term intake of (too) much protein in humans. Barzel et al. (1998) also describe the effect of over-acidification of the body through excessive protein intake and the associated compensation through bone loss and thus calcium loss.In connection with protein diets for weight reduction
column16: St. Jeor et al. (2001) write that there are no scientific long-term studies that prove the effectiveness and safety of such diets. High-protein diets even prevent the necessary requirements of important vitamins and minerals from being met due to the restriction of certain groups of nutrients. LM groups. Furthermore
column17: there is a general risk - despite "high protein" - of a deficiency of essential amino acids if the biological value of the proteins is not taken into account and the foods are combined accordingly.  In summary
column18: the excessive intake of proteins does not represent an acute danger for the Swiss population
column19: but long-term damage is to be expected.##True#27.01.2023 00:00:00#02.03.2025 00:00:00#30#true#20#`

column1: 230#F-2023-013#Grayanotoxin in honey#The European Commission asked EFSA for a scientific opinion on the risks for human health of the presence of grayanotoxins (GTXs) in ‘certain honey’ from Ericaceae plants. The risk assessment included all structurally related grayananes occurring with GTXs in ‘certain’ honey. Oral exposure is associated with acute intoxication in humans. Acute symptoms affect the muscles
column2: nervous and cardiovascular systems. These may lead to complete atrioventricular block
column6: syncope and respiratory depression. For acute effects
column7: the CONTAM Panel derived a reference point (RP) of 15.3 μg/kg body weight for the sum of GTX I and III based on a BMDL10 for reduced heart rate in rats. A similar relative potency was considered for GTX I. Without chronic toxicity studies
column8: an RP for long-term effects could not be derived. There is evidence for genotoxicity in mice exposed to GTX III or honey containing GTX I and III
column9: showing increased levels of chromosomal damage. The mechanism of genotoxicity is unknown. Without representative occurrence data for the sum of GTX I and III and consumption data from Ericaceae honey
column10: acute dietary exposure was estimated based on selected concentrations for GTX I and III reflecting concentrations measured in ‘certain’ honeys. Applying a margin of exposure (MOE) approach
column11: the estimated MOEs raised health concerns for acute toxicity. The Panel calculated the highest concentrations for GTX I and III below which no acute effects would be expected following ‘certain honey’ consumption. The Panel is 75% or more certain that the calculated highest concentration of 0.05 mg for the sum of GTX I and III per kg honey is protective for all age groups regarding acute intoxications. This value does not consider other grayananes in ‘certain honey’ and does not cover the identified genotoxicity.##True#06.03.2023 00:00:00#01.03.2025 00:00:00#10#false#20#`

column3: use social media platforms to attract attention with compelling narratives

column1: 236#F-2023-019#Antimicrobial resistance genes in probiotic bacteria#Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a major threat to public health. In bacteria
column2: AMR depends on antibiotic resistance genes (ARGs)
column3: some of which are mobile and can transfer their ARGs to other bacteria. This action
column5: involves the transfer of small fragments of DNA between bacteria and is facilitated by plasmids
column6: among other things. If bacteria with mobile ARGs are found in food
column7: they can transmit these ARGs to bacteria in the human digestive tract or to pathogens when ingested
column8: contributing to the emergence of drug-resistant bacteria. Although the extent to which probiotics modulate the microbiome is disputed
column9: it is possible that they contribute to the intestinal resistome by colonising the gut. A recent study conducted in Europe
column10: analysing in detail probiotic bacterial species commonly used in certain foods (fermented and non-fermented) and dietary supplements
column11: suggests that consumption of certain probiotic bacterial strains could contribute to the onset and spread of AMR
column12: as in more than half of AGR-positive samples
column13: at least one gene is linked to a plasmid. The results are consistent with another study concluding that the consumption of probiotic products can lead to the transfer of AGRs to human intestinal bacteria. Similarly
column14: probiotics used to feed livestock can also cause antibiotic-resistant THG in animals. Animals treated with these resistant probiotics are likely to become a possible source of ARG for human consumers after ingestion of meat or dairy products.#Results suggest that the prevalence of mobile ARGs might not be negligible
column15: it might be worthy to consider the development of guidelines to monitor these mobile ARGs.#True#29.04.2023 00:00:00#26.01.2025 00:00:00#10#true#20#`

column5: determined by routine acid-based extraction and analysis
column6: hides a substantial share of dimethylated thioarsenates that have similar or higher cytotoxicities than arsenite. Risk assessments characterizing the in vivo toxicity of rice-derived dimethylated thioarsenates are urgently needed. In the meantime
column7: either more sophisticated methods based on enzymatic extraction and separation of dimethylated oxy- and thioarsenates have to become mandatory or total As should be regulated.Since the publication of the 2009 EFSA opinion on arsenic in food new studies have become available on the toxic effects of organic arsenic. Furthermore it has become clear that dimethylmonothioarsenate (DMMTA) is formed from methyl arsenate due to the application of sulphate fertilisers
column8: and that this substance could be more toxic than methylarsenate. It is therefore appropriate to update the hazard identification and characterisation of organic arsenic. On the basis of the available occurrence data for organic arsenic or literature information on organic arsenic in food
column9: the exposure could be estimated in order to carry out an assessment for the risks for human health related to organic arsenic in food. In view of different properties of the methylated arsenic species
column12: it is appropriate to assess the organic arsenic species in 2 separate opinions: an opinion on methylated arsenic species and an opinion on arsenobetaine
column14: which should also include any other possible organic arsenic species. After finalising the risk assessments on inorganic and organic arsenic
column15: also the combined exposure to inorganic and organic arsenic should be assessed (source: Open EFSA (europa.eu))##True#09.11.2023 00:00:00#10.11.2024 00:00:00#10#false#20#`2022

column1: 254#F-2024-002#Pathogen spillover of Henipavirions driven by environmental changes#Hendra and Nipah virus are emerging zoonotic viruses with high mortality rates in humans and animals. Henipaviruses are harboured in small mammals like fruit bats. The risk of pathogen spillover of Hendra virus to humans is immense and associated with habitat loss of bats through environmental changes driven by climate change. The resulting public health concern is elucidated by a recent outbreak of Nipah virus in Bangladesh. Eight people died from Nipah virus infection after consuming raw date palm sap.##True#22.01.2024 00:00:00#22.01.2025 00:00:00#10#false#20#`

258#F-2024-006#Energy costs : three degrees of change in frozen food#Food freezing
column3: extends product shelf life without detriment to food safety for months while also offering built-in opportunities to optimise utilisation through scheduled consumption. Research has demonstrated that frozen foods results in 47% less household food waste than fresh food categories (Martindale 2014). However
column4: with frozen foods comes a significant energy and greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions challenge to the success of a transition to sustainable coldchains: it is energy intensive to freeze foods and hold them at a sub-zero temperature.  Currently the industry standard set-point is -18°C or lower: a temperature established in the mid-20th century which provides a good margin of safety. Some in the industry think a standard set-point of -15°C would be more appropriate for certain food products and that a requirement to not ‘over-freeze’ could be introduced - without any significant negative impacts on food safety or quality. The change in this temperature could be valuable in the context of reducing the increase in energy demand and GHG emissions from the sector. It would also deliver a substantial commercial benefit to cold-chain operators through reduced energy costs. The central question is : Does increasing the temperature of frozen food storage from -18°C to -15°C pose a risk to food safety
column5: particularly in terms of parasite survival?#The Move To Minus 15°C | Cold Chain Sustainability#True#09.02.2024 00:00:00#30.06.2024 00:00:00#20#true#20#`2021-2022
